# How to Free Up 2 Hours Every Day In Your Growing Business Yourself Up in Any Business

## *A Quick Start Guide to the The Two Unchanging Pillars  Simple Shifts That Our Best Clients Make Once They Start Getting More ClientsHave Freed Up Our Clients Time After Time*

You’ve been able to get your business off the ground and grow a team. You know what it takes to get here\! When you’re in the throes of starting your business, you dream of the day when you don’t have to worry about making your mortgage payment.

Then, when your business finally takes off, it feels like the business also takes over\! It consumes your time, energy, focus, and attention. Some days it’s hard to remember that today’s challenges are the answers to yesterday’s prayers\!

When you’re in the messy middle, it can be hard to know where to focus and what to do. Over the past number of years, we’ve been working with clients to free up themselves (or in some cases, their team) in their business.

We distilled the work that we’ve done into the following quadrant. Throughout this article, you’ll find exercises to complete, along with special instructions at the end. 

With that, let’s get started.

## An Introduction to the Streamlined Business Quadrant

![][image1]  
As we took a look at the projects we’ve done, we’ve noticed our clients often faced one of two problems (and sometimes both).

**For some of them, their information was hidden**. It might have been on paper. It may have lived on a network share as a collection of linked spreadsheets. It might have been stored in multiple software systems. And sometimes, it was in a single software system that was difficult to access.

The problem wasn’t that the information didn’t exist. It usually existed--either in someone’s head or on paper. The problem was that the information wasn’t **visible**.

**For others, their process was unclear**. Different people approached the same task in different ways. As a result, details or deadlines would get missed.

The problem wasn’t that the process didn’t exist. It was simply buried underneath layers of complexity and confusion.

## The Four Types of Teams

As we looked at these businesses, we found we could predict their challenges based on these factors.

When neither of these two pieces were in place, the business operations were chaotic. The team members engaged in a lot of activity, but they spent too much energy for the results they got.

This became better when they had shared knowledge. They knew what was going on. However, if they didn’t have a clear process, they still ended up working very inefficiently.

Conversely, if they had a clear process but they couldn’t access the information they needed, the manager or owner had to constantly be checking in on their work. The manager had to let them know what to work on and how to do it, keeping an eye on their employees’ progress. Unintentionally, they ended up micromanaging their team.

When our clients were able to get their entire team on the same page with shared knowledge and a clear process, the whole operation became easier to run. They had less wasted effort in getting things done. They had few miscommunications. Their employees were focused and clear on what needed to be done.

## Applying This to Your Business

This quadrant can be transformed into a simple diagnostic. First, let’s summarize what we covered.

The two primary challenges we see businesses facing are:

* Lack of shared knowledge  
* Lack of clear process

If you don’t have shared knowledge, you’ll end up having a few people being the slowdown for the entire business. If you don’t have a clear process, you’ll end up needing to micromanage everything.

To self-diagnose, you can approach this quadrant in two ways. The first way is by looking *inside* the quadrant. Ask yourself these questions.

(Yes, I’m encouraging you to take 10 minutes to do this RIGHT NOW. If you like, call one or more team members into your office to talk it through.)

1\. What parts of the business are inefficient? (These are likely parts of the business that need a clear process, or need systems supporting that process.)  
																																																																	

2\. What parts of the business need to be micromanaged? (These are likely parts of the business that need better visibility into information needed to do the work.)  
																																																																	

The second way is by looking *outside* the quadrant. Ask yourself these questions:

3\. Where is information hiding in my business? (These are likely parts that are being micromanaged.)  
																																																																	

4\. Where are the steps unclear in my business? (These are likely parts that are inefficient.)  
																																																																	

Take time to sit down and write out the answers to these questions. This will help you pinpoint the one or two areas in your business to focus on for immediate wins.

Once you’ve done that, I encourage you to reach out to Ian to process what you’ve found. He’s the first point of contact for all our clients. He helps them nail down their focus, what they want to accomplish, and take a look at the best path to get there.

If you include a copy of your answers (which we’ll keep confidential) within the next 30 days, I’ve instructed him to send you a copy of a second part of this article. That part goes into the practical examples from ourselves and our clients. It includes tools that you can apply to your business.
